1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 85 (1993) 305-325 305 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V., Amsterdam M246 Metal-support interaction effects in the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol with nickel catalysts supported on AIP04 and on other conventional non-reducible compounds Juan M. Campelo, Rafael Guardeno, Diego Luna* and Jose M. Marinas Department of Organic Chemistry, University of Cordoba, E-14004 Cordoba (Spain) Julian Morales and Jose L. Tirado Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Cordoba, E-14004 Cordoba (Spain) (Received September 15,1992; accepted July 20,1993 ) Abstract The liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol has been carried out on nickel catalysts at 20 wt.-% supported on different AlP04, AIP04-AI203 and AlPO4-5102 systems. Furthermore, some conventional non-reducible compounds, such as Si02, A120s, active carbon or a natural sepiolite were also used as supports. In addition, the effects of nickel loading and Ni-Cu alloying were studied using carbon as the metal support. The relative adsorption constants, KT,D, were also obtained from the relative reactivities, RT,D, obtained in the consecutive hydrogenation process and the corresponding individual hydrogenation rates of 1,4-butynediol and 1,4-butenediol. These values were used to follow the changes in the electronic structure of supported nickel crystallites. Besides, structural defects of supported-nickel crystallites such as 'twin faults', 'atacking faults' and'microstrains', were determined by X-ray diffraction line broadening analysis. These parameters were used for measuring the participation of geometric support effects in the catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts. TEM measurements coupled with digital image processing were also used to measure nickel particle sizes. Results obtained in the correlation between kinetic data and structural defects in supported-nickel crystallites as well as with textural and acid-basic properties of the supports indicated that electronic and geometric effects were simultaneously developed throughout metal-support interactions. Key words: AIP04;1,4-butynediol; hydrogenation; nickel Introduction In heterogeneous metal catalysis, the belief that the support is merely an inert substrate for metal particles, used mainly to provide well-dispersed catalysts to prevent sintering and deactivation, has not been valid for at least thirty years [ 1 ] , and metal-support interaction effects have been shown to play an important role in applied catalysis [ 2 ] . Thus, it is often found that *Corresponding author. 0304-5102/93/$06.00 1993 - Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. 306 Juan M. Campelo et ad. / J. Mol. Catal. 85 (1993) 305-325 support materials modify not only the chemical reactivity of metal catalysts but also their capacity to adsorb gases. With respect to this, the subject of a great part of current research in catalysis by metals is strong metal-support interaction effects (SMSI). This refers to the inability of some supported metal particles to adsorb hydrogen and/or carbon monoxide after a reduction at temperatures where the support is known to be at least partially reduced [ 3 ] . This behaviour, initially associated with reducible transition metal oxides like Ti02 [ 4 ] or Nb205 [ 5 ] , has now been extended to non-transition metal oxides like A1203 [ 6 ] and Si02 [ 7 ] or some materials such as silicon carbide [ 8 ] or AIP04 [9,10]. Consequently, the behaviour of some metal-supported catalysts with respect to adsorption and catalytic activity seems to be similar to that observed in Ti02-supported catalysts, although the mechanism of this metal-support interaction could be different for different systems. Since the first discovery made by Solymosi [ 11 ] and Schwab [ 12 ] concerning the dominant role of electronic interactions in determining metal-support interaction effects, many studies have demonstrated that a change in the electron density of the metal, because of the transfer of electrons from support to metal or vice versa, can significantly modify chemisorption and catalytic properties [ 13-16 ] . However, other explanations for this behaviour have been suggested, such as different coverage models or `decoration' [ 17-19 ] or morphological changes in the active metal [ 20 ] . Besides, suggestions have been made that any of the models alone cannot explain metal-support interaction effects in real catalysts [ 21,22 ] and energetic, electronic and geometric properties of supported metal particles are simultaneously modified by electronic metalsupport interaction and by changes from bulk to atomic properties of the metal. Both effects become more important as the particle size of the metal becomes smaller and it will not always be easy to distinguish between the relative contributions of electronic and structural or geometric effects on catalytic (and/ or chemisorptive) properties of supported metal [ 23 ] . As a part of our work on the catalytic behaviour of AIP04 supported nickel catalysts in several liquid-phase hydrogenation reactions (9,24-32), the present paper reports on research into the relative influence of geometric and electronic effects of supports on the catalytic behaviour of such catalysts. In this respect, the existence of metal-support interactions on AIP04 supported nickel catalysts has been extensively based not only on the kinetic behaviour of catalysts [9,10,24-34 ] and on suppression of hydrogen chemisorption [ 10,31,35 ], as is typical of SMSI oxide supports, but also on the help of a poisoning titration method [27 ] and on magnetic studies [36,37 ] . These magnetic studies, through changes in the Curie point of the supported nickel, indicated a bulk electronic interaction between the nickel metal and the phosphate-containing supports, but not on other interacting supports. The reason for such a different behaviour is not yet known. As a reaction probe, we have selected the liquid-phase semihydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol. The results previously obtained [32] indicate that catalytic Juan M. Campelo et al. / J. Mot. Catal. 85 (1993) 305-325 307 activity, selectivity and catalyst metal surface area are closely correlated to some textural and/or acid-base properties of the corresponding support. Thus, from kinetic analysis of the consecutive hydrogenation, we can obtain KT,D, the relative adsorption constant of the triple bond with respect to the double bond for different catalysts [30,38,39 ] . These values, according to the results previously described for the competitive hydrogenation of toluene and benzene on several supported noble metals [40,41 ], may be used to follow the changes in the electronic structure of supported nickel crystallites. Thus, KTD values, as well as all the other kinetic parameters obtained in the liquid-phase consecutive hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol, could be correlated with the support acid-base properties of the nickel-supported catalyst, with the metal loading or the presence of a second metal, such as copper, in order to test the electronic influence on metal-support interaction effects. Otherwise, some correlation between support textural properties and kinetic parameters would be related to geometric effects of the support. On the other hand, in catalysis on single metal crystals, step or corner atoms show different catalytic properties than terrace atoms [ 42 ] . However, although there is evidence to suggest that crystal defects may provide active sites in supported metal catalysts, the exact nature and function of the sites is not yet well known. With regard to this, it was recently established that in some catalytic reactions, not only metallic dispersion but also the microstructure of metal particles must be considered as factors controlling selectivity [43 ] . In other ways, defects in the broad sense include different effects that should be evaluated separately. Thus, X-ray diffraction line broadening analysis (XRDLBA) has been extensively used to evaluate defect structures in metals, averaged to a significantly large volume sample [ 44-47 ] . The different measurements include the size of the coherent diffraction domains in selected crystallographic directions and the content of microstrains, as referred to the variations of interplanar spacing due to the presence of dislocations. Both parameters can be easily determined from the Lorentzian and Gaussian components of line breadth, respectively [ 48 ] . Further analysis of other effects, such as the asymmetric broadening of the profiles and hence a shift of the center of gravity of peaks, may provide information on the presence of twin faults [ 49 ] . A shift in the position of the XRD peak can also be used to identify the occurrence of stacking faults in the metal lattice [ 50 ] . In the present paper, structural defects of supported-nickel crystallites are evaluated by XRDLBA. These parameters and those obtained by using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) will be correlated with textural and acidbase properties of solids used as supports in order to evaluate the potential correlation between the two kinds of parameters. Furthermore, the influence of former structural parameters on catalytic activity and selectivity in the liquid-phase semihydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol will also be determined. 308 Juan M. Campelo et al. / J. Mol. Catal. 85 (1993) 305-325 Experimental Catalysts preparation Catalysts containing 20 wt.-% nickel were prepared by impregnation of eleven different supports to incipient wetness with 10 M aqueous nickel nitrate following the procedure previously described [ 9,24-32 ] . They were dried, crushed and screened to particle size < 0.149 mm (10 mesh size), reduced in an ultrapure hydrogen stream (1.7 cmI s-1) at 400 C for 4 h, and then cooled to room temperature in the same hydrogen stream and stored in sealed glass bottles until required. Three different aluminum orthophosphates were prepared according to Kearby [ 51 ] by precipitation from aqueous solutions of AIC13 6H20 and H3P04 (85 wt.-%) at pH=6.1 at the `precipitation end point', with ammonium hydroxide solution (AIP04-A), ethylene oxide (AIP04-E) and propylene oxide (AIP04-P). Similarly, another three AIP04-A1203-A, E and P systems (75: 25 wt.-%) were obtained, as well as an AIP04-Si02 (20:80 wt.-%), using ethylene oxide as the precipitation agent. The solid obtained was then washed with isopropyl alcohol and dried at 120 C for 24 h. The resulting powder screened at 0.120-0.149 mm was calcined for 3 h in an electric muffle furnace at 650 C. Furthermore, some common commercial materials such as a silica from Merck (Kieselgel 60, 70-230 mesh), Si02; an alumina (aluminum oxide active acidic for chromatography) from Merck, A1203 and an active carbon from Panreac, C; as well as natural sepiolite from Vallecas (Madrid), supplied by Tolsa S.A., TABLE 1 Textural and acid-base properties of different supports Support SBBTB V b d ` Acidity' vs. PYe Basicityd vs. BA' AIP0,-A 156 0.68 3.6 190 200 AlP04-E 242 0.52 4.3 267 266 AlP0,-P 228 0.94 2.5 227 166 AlP0-A1203-A 244 0.37 3.1 187 535 AIP04-AI203-E 242 0.54 4.5 208 577 A'P04-AI203-P 319 0.68 4.2 326 774 AIP04-Si02 327 0.46 3.0 380 70 A1203 72 0.24 2.7 23 191 Si02 366 0.68 3.5 206 164 C 743 0.55 1.5 124 132 Sep 203 0.54 5.3 31 174 'Surface area by B.E.T. method in m2 g-'. bPore volume in m2 g-1. Catal. 85 (1993) 305-325 309 Sep; were also used as the support after undergoing the same calcination treatment. In addition, in order to minimize the support effect in the evaluation of metal loading and the role of Cu in Ni-Cu alloying, carbon was used as the support of three catalysts constituted by nickel supported at 5,10 and 20 wt.- as well and four Ni-Cu bimetallic systems containing Ni at 20 wt.-% and Cu loadings between 0.1 and 7 wt.-%. The textural properties of supports (surface area, pore volume and main pore diameter) determined by nitrogen adsorption have been published elsewhere [ 32,52 ] and are summarized in Table 1, where the surface basicity and acidity are also collected. These values were determined by a apectrophotometric method described elsewhere [ 53 ] , that allows titration of the amount of irreversibly adsorbed benzoic acid (BA, pKH=4.19) or pyridine (PY, pKa = 5.25) employed as titrant agents of basic and acid sites, respectively. The monolayer coverage at equilibrium at 25 C, Xm (in umol g-1), is accomplished by applying the Langmuir adsorption isotherm, and is assumed as a measure of the acid or basic sites corresponding to the specific pK8 of the base or acid used as the titrant. Catalyst characterization XRD patterns were recorded with a Siemens D500 diffractometer working with CuKa radiation monochromated by a graphite crystal. Data collection was performed with a DACO-MP system. The profiles for XRDLBA were recorded by the `step scan' technique with a step width of 0.02 2O. Background was automatically corrected by the DACO-MP system and a2-elimination was carried out by the Rachinger method [ 54 ] . Results obtained in all cases were in the form shown in Fig. 1 for different Ni/AIP04 catalysts. Bulk Ni powder was used as the standard for the correction of instrumental broadening and Si powder for peak position, [26] 111, measurements. Position shifts were used to identify the occurrence of stacking faults in the metal lattice [ 50 ] . Single-line broadening analysis was performed by profile fitting to Pearson-VII functions [ 55 ] .Crystallite size, e, and microstrains, e, were computed from the Cauchy and Gauss components of the pure profile integral breadths. These were deconvoluted from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) to integral breadth ratio, ss. The difference between peak and centroid position, 20c -20p, was also computed to evaluate the possible presence of twin faults. The metal surface area, SN;, of supported nickel catalysts was obtained from the average crystallite size diameter, D, determined by X-ray diffraction according to the method of Moss [ 56 ] by using the classical Scherrer equation [ 57 ] as has been described elsewhere [ 9,24-32 ] . Thus, the most common evaluation of crystallite size from FWHM was also carried out, assuming that the complete broadening was due to small crystallite effects. The initial reaction rates in triple and double bond hydrogenation (rT and rD, respectively) were determined by taking the initial slope of the plot of the hydrogen pressure decrease at the manometer versus time. These kinetic results are expressed as specific areal rates, in mol s-1 mN2, defined as the activity per unit surface area of nickel metal in order to compare the activity of the different systems in terms of specific catalytic activity. They were obtained from the initial reaction rates and the metallic surface areas of catalysts, SN; in Tables 2 and 3. Consecutive hydrogenation runs were followed by GLC analysis of the reaction mixtures at appropriate intervals of hydrogen uptake (Fig. 3-A). The reaction product analysis was performed with a Hewlett-Packard 5830 gas chromatograph fitted with an H.P. 3396A integrator, equipped with a column packed with 5% carbowax-20 M in 80/100 Chromosorb GAW-DMCS. Neither isomerization nor hydrogenolysis products were detected in any of the cases. Results and discussion As can be seen in Tables 2, 3 and 4, close agreement in nickel particle sizes was obtained with both techniques, that is, with TEM coupled with digital image processing and XRD data obtained by the usual Scherrer treatment or 314 Juan M. Campelo et al. / J. Mol. CataL 85 (1993) 305-325 by using a complete XRDLBA including the separation of crystallite size and microstrains. However, the relationships between different estimates of particle dimensions obtained in the regression analysis of all well correlated parameter pairs shown in Table 5 cast new light on the accuracy of the different estimation methods commonly used for the characterization of supported metal catalysts. First, a highly significant relationship is found between D and E, crystallite sizes derived from the Scherrer and Pearson-VII profile fitting methods. However, the positive slope of the regression line has a value lower than unity and the intercept is close to 30 A. This result should not be surprising, as the Scherrer method ascribes the complete broadening to small crystallite effects, leading to lower sizes than the `true' values when microstrain contents are high [ 59 ] . In addition, the Scherrer estimates used the full width at half maximum instead of the integral breadths used in the Pearson-VII method, which is well known [55] to condition a greater size. The higher degree of accuracy of the Pearson-VII method is also evident in the regression parameters between the average crystallite size derived from this function and the various diameters derived from TEM measurements. Although the relationship with the result of the Scherrer method is also statistically significant, the slopes are closer to unity and the intercepts closer to zero in the former case. In this respect, the best agreement was obtained between crystallite size from Pearson-VII, e, and nominal diameter, Dn, from TEM. However, it can be concluded that for comparative purposes with the absolute value of crystallite size, the trend in Scherrer size fits TEM parameters with acceptable significance. According to the results previously obtained with the same substrates [32 ], in this range of operating variables, the kinetic data obtained under the present experimental conditions are free from transport influences. Juan M. Campelo et al. / J. Mol. Catd 85 (1993) 305-325 315 variation of the hydrogenation rate with catalyst loading and its independence with respect to the agitation speed above 200 strokes min -1 let us assume the absence of external diffusion control. The average particle size of the catalyst used ( < 0.149 nm) was such that the reactions were not influenced by internal diffusion, according to results previously obtained for allyl [ 28 ] and propargyl [30,31 ] alcohols under the same selected conditions. On the other hand, the independence of the hydrogenation rate from the initial hydrogen pressure as well as from the substrate concentrations in the ranges studied (0.3-0.7 MPa and 0.5-3.0 M, respectively) let us assume zero order kinetics in hydrogen pressure as well as in substrate concentrations. This assumption is also consistent with the linear plots in the lowering of the hydrogen pressure vs. time [ 60 ] . Otherwise, taking into account the zero-order kinetics obtained with respect to the substrate concentration as well as to the hydrogen pressure, the specific areal rates (r, and rD, respectively) reported in Tables 5 and 6 can be used directly as the reaction constant values to obtain the relative adsorption constant of double bond with respect to triple bond for different catalysts, KT,D, by using the corresponding relative reactivity, RT,D, determined by introducing a modification [30,38,39 ] into the classical Rader-Smith kinetic equation [61 ] of competitive hydrogenations: I I RT,D =rDKT,D c lOgCT /log CD - (CT - CT) (3 ) where CT and CD are concentrations of T and D (cis-2-butene-1,4-diol and 2butene-1,4-diol, respectively) when CT= CD. According to the results in Table 6, all supports enhance the value of the ratio rT/rD to a variable degree with respect to the Ni in bulk, while KT,D exhibits the opposite behaviour. Furthermore, catalysts with the lowest KT,D, such as Ni/Si02, Ni/C or Ni/AIP04-A, exhibit specific catalytic activity values, rT and rD, respectively, higher than the Ni-bulk catalyst. This behaviour, identical to that previously found for the consecutive hydrogenation of propargyl alcohols [ 30 ] , may be associated with electronic metal-support interaction effects. Thus, for a pair of hydrocarbons with different electronic structures, any change in the structure of the surface sites results in a modification of the relative adsorption constant value. In this respect, the modification of the electronic structure due to environmental effects (support acidity, electric field of cation adsorbates, or Pt-Zr bimetallic alloys) was monitored with a higher degree of sensitivity than that obtained by using physical techniques [ 40,41,67,68 ] . In this respect, a great deal of information about electronic metal-support interaction effects could be obtained from a direct correlation between these kinetic data, and the corresponding values of textural and acid-base properties of the supports. Moreover, the role of geometric effects of supports in determining the catalytic behaviour of supported metal catalysts could be obtained from some correlation between kinetic data and structural defects of supported-nickel crystallites. Thus we developed a correlation matrix using all the data in Tables 1, 2 and 6. The corresponding values of slopes and intercepts obtained in the regression analysis of those well-correlated parameter pairs are collected in Table 8, where the corresponding significance levels are also indicated. As can be seen, significance levels under 90% are not considered. According to these results, some kinetic parameters of catalysts are well correlated with BET surface area as well as with the surface basicity determined by titration with benzoic acid. However, the best results were obtained when kinetic parameters were correlated with the number of basic sites per unit of support BET surface area, that is, to the surface density of basic sites or specific basicity of supports. Thus, according to the slopes (a values) in Table 8, on increasing the surface density of basic sites, KT,D values increase, while the corresponding rT and rD values decrease. This consequently explains the complex correlation obtained between the surface density of basic sites and RT,D (or S). Furthermore, the compensation between the two parameters rT/ rD and KT,D also shown in Table 8, determines the relatively very close RT,D values and, consequently, the narrow selectivity (83-94%) gap. All these facts could be explained within the framework of the prevailing role of an electronic transfer between support and metal in determining the metal-support interaction effects. Thus, according to Bartholomew et al. [69 ] , an electron transfer between the basic sites on the support and nickel atoms increases the d-band concentration of electrons in the metal crystallites leading to a catalytic behaviour more characteristic of copper. Furthermore, taking into account that the nucleophilic character of an alkyne bond is higher than that of the alkene one, on decreasing the electrophile character of nickel surface active sites, selectivity in the competitive adsorption of former molecules will increase with respect to later ones. Thus, the highest values in KTD could be obtained when (due to the higher number of basic sites in support) the so much lower electrophile Juan M. Campelo et al. / J. Mod. Catat 85 (1993) 305-325 319 character of nickel surface atoms does not allow the adsorption of the competing alkene molecules which exhibit a lower nucleophilic character. On the other hand, according to the results in Table 8, the existence of electronic effects does not exclude the simultaneous presence of geometric effects of supports on the catalytic hydrogenation process. Thus, we can see several correlations between kinetic parameters and those parameters related to structural defects of supported-nickel crystallites such as microstrains, e, twin faults, 20c -29p, and stacking faults, 20. Besides, the origin of crystallite structural defects may be obtained from textural and acid-base properties of supports, according to the corresponding correlations obtained between crystallite microstrains and the BET surface area, pore diameter and surface density of the basic sites of supports as well as between crystallite twin faults and the BET surface area, pore volume and surface acidity of supports. It is worth noting that the BET surface area of the catalyst support significantly affects crystal perfection in the metal particles. Thus, a high BET surface area conditions an enhanced asymmetry of the profiles that can be related to the presence of antiphase domains in the metal particles, as stated in previous literature [49 ] . On the contrary, high BET surface values imply a low content in microstrains. This, in turn, implies that the extensive twinning relaxes the internal strains in the [ 111 ] direction of the metal lattice. A close relationship between stacking faults and twinning with crystallite size was also obtained. The former parameters increased when crystallite size decreased In this respect, crystallite defects probably act on kinetic parameters through the specific number of surface-active sites of nickel particles, n. (number of active sites per unit surface area), while the final electronic level of nickel crystallites do it through changing the `turnover frequency', TOF (the rate of the reaction expressed in moles per exposed metal atom and per unit time). The defects here considered may be the same described by Somorjai [42,70] as steps, terraces and kinks, which set up the surface density of metal active sites. However, aside from ne values, different electronic levels in Ni d orbitals produce different TOF values. Thus, specific catalytic activity (rT and rD) obtained from the product of the two parameters (neX TOF) ought to be necessarily related to both electronic and geometric crystallite parameters. The relationship between particle size and catalytic activity reported by many authors [ 71 ] may be due to the existence of constant TOF values with different surface densities of metal active sites associated with crystallite defects. In spite of the close relationship between stacking faults and twinning with crystallite size here obtained (Table 8 shows that former parameters increase when crystallite size decrease so that, on decreasing particle size, imperfections are also increased), the dependence of rD and rT with respect crystallite size values could be due to the existence of different TOF values for different Ni/support catalysts associated with varying electronic metal-support interaction effects developed through basic sites of supports. Thus, with the help of a poisoning titration method [ 27 ] , using n-butanethiol as the poison, we determined dif- 320 Juan M. Campelo et al. / J. Mot. Catal. 85 (1993) 305-325 ferent surface densities of Ni-active sites and different TOFs for different supports in the liquid-phase catalytic hydrogenation of 1-hesene over various supported nickel catalysts. The results obtained in the correlation between kinetic data (Table 7) and structural defects of supported-nickel crystallites with different nickel loadings and Ni-Cu bimetallic alloying (Table 3) also indicate that electronic and geometric effects of supports, through their textural and acid-base properties, simultaneously act on the catalytic behaviour of Ni-supported catalysts. Thus, in Table 9, we can see how nickel loading acts not only on particle size and structural defects of crystallites such as microstrains but also on KT,D, a kinetic parameter directly related to the electronic level of nickel surface active sites. Table 10 also shows how copper alloying not only affects the latter parameter related to electronic effects, but also stacking faults, a parameter related to structural defects. Thus, the specific number of surface-active sites of nickel particles, n and the degree of electron transfer are simultaneously related not only to the nature of the support but also to the metal/support ratio and to the possible presence of a second metal. With respect to the influence of nickel loading and copper alloying on selectivity as well as on RT,, we find that both parameters affect not only KT,D but also the quotient rT/rD (Tables 9 and 10). Thus the complexity of (3) gives rise to the difficulty in directly obtaining some correlation between selectivity or RT,D and the corresponding Ni wt.-% and Cu wt.-% parameters, respectively. However, according to the results in Table 8, we must recognize the complex influence of support parameters not only on catalytic activity, rT and rD, but also on the selectivity and RT,D of supported nickel catalysts. Similarly, metal loading and Ni-Cu alloying effects may be better explained within the framework of a simultaneous electronic and structural metal-support interaction effect. In this respect, steps going from support properties to the corresponding catalytic behaviour of Ni (or a bimetallic NiCu) catalyst could be summarized in the Scheme 1. Consequently, independent of the SMSI mechanism developed with Ti02 and other reducible supports, where the participation of different coverage models or `decorations' would be possible [ 17-19 ] , according to the present results the kinetic behaviour of nickel catalysts supported on AlP04and on other non-reducible supports may be explained by the simultaneous participation of electronic and structural effects in metal-support interaction. On the other hand, based on these results and according to a previous work [30], we may conclude that the modification introduced into the classical Rader-Smith relation [61 ] allows us obtain RT,D and KT,D values in consecutive processes such as the selective hydrogenation of alkynea within the framework of Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetics. These kinetic parameters can give us valuable information not only concerning the hydrogenation mechanism of double and triple bond but also on the parameters affecting the selectivity of the process as well as the electronic level of supported nickel, which is modified 322 TEXTURAL AND ACID-BASE PROPERTIES OF SUPPORTS AND Wt% Ni LOADING STRUCTURAL DEFECTS OF SUPPORTED-NICKEL CRYSTALLITES SPECIFIC NUMBER OF CATALYTICALLY ACTIVE SURFACE-NICKEL ATOMS SPECIFIC CATALYTIC ACTIVITIES, rT AND rp Scheme 1. An increase in electronic density in Ni d-band promotes a variable increase in KT,D, so that this kinetic parameter is a useful teat in evaluating the existence of electronic metalsupport interaction effects. Finally, results obtained by using Pearson-VII functions in the X-ray diffraction line broadening analysis to evaluate structural defects in supported nickel crystallites indicate that it may constitute an adequate technique for measuring the existence, extent and participation of geometric support effects in the catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts. Besides, crystallite size values thus obtained were in better agreement with TEM measurements than those obtained by using the classical Scherrer equation. However in this respect, while structural defects in metal crystallites promote a notable influence in catalytic activity and selectivity, their contribution to the line broadening is less important so that classical Scherrer equation actually constitutes an adequate technique for measuring average crystallite size diameters. Tirado Department of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Córdoba, E-14004 Córdoba Spain The liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol has been carried out on nickel catalysts at 20 wt.-% supported on different AlPO4, AlPO4Al2O3 and AlPO4-SiO2 systems. Furthermore, some conventional non-reducible compounds, such as SiO2, Al2O3, active carbon or a natural sepiolite were also used as supports. In addition, the effects of nickel loading and NiCu alloying were studied using carbon as the metal support. The relative adsorption constants, K T,D, were also obtained from the relative reactivities, R T,D, obtained in the consecutive hydrogenation process and the corresponding individual hydrogenation rates of 1,4-butynediol and 1,4-butenediol. These values were used to follow the changes in the electronic structure of supported nickel crystallites. Besides, structural defects of supported-nickel crystallites such as ‘twin faults’, ‘stacking faults’ and ‘microstrains’, were determined by X-ray diffraction line broadening analysis. These parameters were used for measuring the participation of geometric support effects in the catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts. TEM measurements coupled with digital image processing were also used to measure nickel particle sizes. Results obtained in the correlation between kinetic data and structural defects in supported-nickel crystallites as well as with textural and acid—basic properties of the supports indicated that electronic and geometric effects were simultaneously developed throughout metal—support interactions.
